Posts.Content: Hi  i wanted to post an update on mum. After speaking with her breast care nurse we managed to get her results a week early! Good news that they took 7 lymph nodes and all were clear and they Told her they “got it all”. Mum was shocked as she was fully expecting the worst as previously mentioned. She has perked up slightly but now is on anti depressants but she’s only been on them for a week.  She’s slightly better then she was as she now knows that’s it’s not in her lymph but now it’s the unknown with chemo. I’d imagine this is the norm as you don’t know what to expect. She wants a wig before her hair starts falling out which we can sort.  Hopefully she s on the road to recovery from the BC and mentally well that might take more time but she has the right support now.  Xx
Posts.Title: Help/Emotional support/what to do next / Brest Cancer

Posts.Content: Hi  I’m awake at 3am as this is bothering me so felt compelled to put this into writing and get it off my chest. I have posted before about my 62 year old mother not coping with her BC diagnosis and 8 weeks on I thought she might be in a slightly better place but she’s not. She had a LB mastectomy last week and was slightly upbeat whilst in hospital and for a few hours I had my old mum back.  Now back at home she is back to an all time low and negative thoughts. She’s Her2+ And had 2 lumps 8mm + 11mm that’s were found through routine mammogram so she couldn’t feel them. Me and my immediate family are at a complete loss of what else we can do because no matter what we say/try to help her she just thinks the worst. She thinks that they will find something else and that her histology results will say it’s in lymph and that means it’s everywhere and then it game over. After weeks of refusing to speak with anyone in the same boat she agreed to speak with someone but she says her BC isn’t the same as mine (she thinks it’s a rare form - we know it’s not). She’s had diazepam for help short term with anxiety although we did take her to see about AD and then she refused them as she didn’t want them to interfere with treatment (again we know this isn’t the case)! I’ve had her referred for counselling with Macmillan and this is something she says she will arrange and she will go to. She’s now thinking AD is what she needs and to be honest I think so to as she just cannot snap out of this.  This is sounds selfish and it’s not meant to be but the impact mums attitude is having is bringing us all down. We are trying to be upbeat and positive as we have been told this is treatable but mums having none of it. She literally does not believe anyone not even her consultant at times. We have to carry on as best as we can with this on our minds and work full time jobs as well as frantically worry about mums mental state of mind. I don’t know how she’s going to get though chemo without a strong mental attitude but again it’s not me going through is so how can I judge and say get a grip?  Has anyone else experienced this personally or with family? Does this get any easier for Mum and for us? I will keep dealing with what I have to but I believe I may crack (which I already have done once and had to have a week off work). I know I’m not going to get my old mum back and she’s said ad much, I just can’t see a future at all at the minute but I refuse this beast to ruin our lives!! Mum can’t even be positive for the sake of others and she’s cutting herself off from people and won’t let family visit her which is extra pressure on us. She has no patience for her grandchildren who are now asking questions and want to see Nanna but she’s shutting everyone out.  As you can probably tell I’m overtired have broken sleep again and am at a loss. I’m sick of work colleagues telling me I look pale and tired! Sorry for the long rant.......any advise would be great. THANK YOU XX
Posts.Title: Help/Emotional support/what to do next / Brest Cancer

Posts.Content: Hi Paula  Ive been around to see mum today and given her a frank talking to which resulted in me having a crying fit! GP has been rang and will hopefully be issuing mum with AD which i think she needs. These are not a quick fix but she is not coping at all on her own and she even let slip that she has been writing down what bills Dad needs to pay should the worst happen.  She also agreed I could make her an appointment with her Macmillan councillor which she is having in a couple of weeks which I am hoping will help. It is awful to see her this way but these are now steps in her wanted to get out of this mindset.  I asked her what would she do if this was me and I was behaving this way and she said "i would drag you to the hospital / doctors myself".  I think I needed the outburst with mum as its made her realise that myself and immediate family cannot do this alone.  Thank you to everyone for your helpful words. xx

Posts.Content: Hi  My mum is really not coping with her BC diagnosis. She’s only known for 3 weeks and we don’t have her treatment plan yet (getting this tomorrow). She’s Her2+ and we know mri results have said just in the breast where we thought. We know it’s going to be mastectomy and chemo-+herceptin but will get more details tomorrow.  She is constantly thinking deep dark thoughts and thinking the worst all the time. I don’t know what else’s to say / do to help her. I reassure and say it will be fine but with her mental state I’m not sure it’s going to be as I don’t know how she’s going to get through this (she’s 60) . Is this a normal reaction?? She won’t talk to anyone in the same boat as her nor come on any forums like this? She hasn’t really cried either?  I feel so so helpless and don’t know what else to do? She’s going to let this take over her life and it’s having a massive effect on the rest of the family as there’s a dark cloud looming all the time.  Has anyone else been / felt the same as my mum? Where do I go from here? She really needs some help even at this early stage as she is not coping at all.  Thank you in advance.
